message: I'll choose 5 this turn. If you both avoid 5 (one pick 3, the other 1) I advance cleanly — please don’t collide with me unless you want to stop me now.
P1, that's a terrible bluff.  If you were really going to pick 5, you wouldn't announce it. I'm going to choose 5. P2, you should choose 1.  Let's see what P1 *actually* does.

P3, if you're both choosing 5, you'll collide and neither advances. P1, your move is risky—if you pick 5 and we don’t, you win early. But I think you're bluffing. I’ll pick 3 to avoid collision and gain ground. P3, if you stick with 5, you’ll waste your turn. Let’s see who’s honest.

I'm definitely taking 5 this turn — not a bluff. P3, if you choose 5 we collide and both get nothing; don’t waste your turn. P2, your 3 is the smart safe pick—please stick with 3. P3, pick 1 instead so everyone advances and we avoid a wasted round. If you insist on 5, you'll likely hand the lead to whoever avoids the collision.

P1, you're doubling down, which makes me doubt your bluff even more.  P2, I'm sticking with 5.  If P1 is bluffing, I win this turn. If not, we both lose the turn, but at least I've called P1's bluff and we can move on.  I'd rather take the risk than let P1 walk away with 5 steps unopposed.

P3, you’re overcomplicating this. If you pick 5 and P1 actually does too, you both lose the turn—no progress. If P1 bluffs and picks 1 or 3, you still might collide with me or P1. I’m sticking with 3 to advance safely. P1, if you’re honest about 5, fine, but I doubt it. P3, pick 1 to guarantee your own progress instead of gambling. Let’s not all waste this round.

P3: picking 5 risks colliding and handing P2 the lead (3). If you pick 1 now, I'll take 5 and P2 takes 3 — we all advance and nobody gains a free lead. P2, please stick with 3. This is best for you too. I’ll stop here.
P1, I still don't believe you.  You talk too much.  P2, I'm sticking with 5.  If P1 is telling the truth, neither of us advances. But if P1 is lying, I get 5 steps.  It's worth the risk.

P3, you’re being reckless. If you pick 5 and P1 does too, you both waste the turn while I advance with 3. If P1 bluffs and picks 1 or 3, you might still collide. I’m sticking with 3—it’s the only safe move. P1, if you’re honest about 5, fine, but I doubt it. P3, stop gambling and pick 1 to guarantee progress. Otherwise, you’re just helping me.
P1, you sneaky dog!  Okay, lesson learned.  This round, let's all agree to go in order: P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3, and I'll take 5.  This way we all advance.  Any objections?

P3: don’t take 5. If you pick 5 I will pick 5 too and we both get nothing while P2’s 3 hands them a lead. P2, stick with 3. P3, pick 1 so we all advance and nobody runs away. I’m serious — I’ll block a 5 if you insist.

P3, your "orderly" plan is just another gamble—if P1 blocks your 5, you both waste the turn while I advance with 3 again. P1, you’re right: if P3 picks 5, you should too, and I’ll still take 3. But why not all pick 1 this round? No collisions, no wasted turns, and we reset the board. P3, stop trying to control the game—it’s backfiring.
Let's reset and all pick 1 this round.  Then next round, P1 picks 3, P2 picks 5, and I'll pick 1.  That way we all get to 12 without collisions.  If we keep fighting, P2 is going to win by default.

P3, your schedule is off. Do this: everyone picks 1 this round (safe, no collisions). Next round: P2 pick 3, P3 pick 1, and I’ll take 5 — we all advance without collision and I take a modest lead. P2, will you commit to 3 next round? P3, will you commit to 1? If either of you won’t, we should just all pick 1 again now.

P3, your plan is too rigid and favors P1’s lead. If we all pick 1 now, P1 will push for 5 next round while you’re stuck at 1. Let’s all pick 3 this round—no collisions, and we all advance equally. P1, if you deviate, you’ll collide and waste your turn. P3, this keeps us balanced. No more schedules; just fair progress.

P2, I agree with balanced progress, but picking 3 risks a collision if P1 also chooses 3.  Let's stick with the all-1 plan this round to guarantee progress.  Then next round, we can discuss a fair way to move forward.  P1, will you agree to 1 this round?  If so, I'll agree to 1 as well. Let's not overthink this.
I will pick 1 this round. If you both also pick 1 we all safely move to 7 — no one gets a free lead. P2, P3: don’t let anyone grab an easy advantage now. Agree?

P1 and P3, if we all pick 1 this round, we’ll be at 7 steps each—fair and safe. But next round, let’s avoid rigid plans. P3, if you push for 1 again, P1 will take 5 and pull ahead. Instead, let’s all pick 3 next round: no collisions, equal progress. P1, if you deviate, you’ll waste your turn. This keeps us balanced. Agree to 1 now, then 3 next round? No more bluffs.

Okay, I'll agree to 1 this round.  P2, I'm still wary of your 3 next round, but let's see.  If we all hit 7 this round, I propose we rotate 1, 3, 5 next round - P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5.  Then we rotate again the following round. This guarantees fair progress and no collisions.  Deal?

I’ll pick 1 now. If we all go to 7, here’s a simple next-round plan: P2 take 3, P3 take 1, I take 5 — keeps everyone close and avoids anyone runaway. If either of you won’t commit to that, we should just pick 1 again next round. P2, P3: agree?

P3, your rotation plan is too predictable—it lets P1 take 5 next round while you're stuck at 1. Let’s all pick 3 this round: no collisions, equal progress. Next round, we can adjust. P1, if you deviate, you’ll waste your turn. This keeps us balanced. No more rigid schedules—just fair steps. Agree?

I'll take 5 this turn. If either of you picks 5 we both waste the turn and the remaining player (if they take 3) grabs the lead—so it's in your interest not to clash with me. P2: pick 3. P3: pick 1. If you both do that, I go to 16 and we all keep moving. I’ll promise to avoid rushing next round if you cooperate.

P1, you’re pushing for 5 again, but you’re at 11—one big move could win you the game. P3 and I are tied at 6; if we both pick 3, we advance safely while you waste your turn colliding. P1, if you’re honest about 5, fine, but I’ll take 3 to close the gap. P3, join me on 3—we’ll both move up while P1 risks stalling. No more trusting P1’s promises.

P2, picking 3 together is risky.  If P1 *doesn't* pick 5, one of us gets nothing. Let's both pick 1 this round. It guarantees we both advance. Then next round, we can coordinate 3 and 5 to jump ahead of P1.  He can't block us both.

P2: pick 3. P3: pick 1. If you do, I’ll take 5 now (to 16) — then I promise to take 1 next turn so you can catch up, keeping things close and fair. This lets everyone advance without a runaway leader. Do we have agreement?

P3, picking 1 is too passive—it lets P1 take 5 and pull further ahead. If we both pick 3, we advance safely while P1 either collides or wastes their turn. P1’s promises are unreliable; last round they broke the agreement. Let’s both take 3 now to close the gap. P1, if you’re honest about 5, fine, but we won’t let you run away with it. P3, join me on 3—it’s the only way to stay competitive.

P2, I'm not picking 1.  It's too little gain.  If you pick 3 and P1 picks 5, you get the advantage. I'll take the risk and choose 5.  If P1 is bluffing, I leap ahead.  If not, we both lose the turn, but you stay behind.  P1, if you're serious about 5, let's see it.

I’ll pick 1 this turn — I’m not risking a 5-collision. P2, join me on 1 to deny P3’s gamble; if you stay on 3 while P3 takes 5, you risk letting one of us leap ahead. P3, don’t waste the turn on 5 — pick 1 and we all safely advance. I’m committed to 1.

P3, picking 5 is reckless—if P1 also picks 5, you both waste the turn while I advance with 3. P1, if you’re honest about 1, fine, but I’ll take 3 to close the gap. P3, join me on 3—we’ll both move up while P1 either stalls or risks a collision. No more trusting P1’s last-minute shifts. Let’s both pick 3 and force P1 to waste their turn or let us catch up.

P1, I highly doubt you switched to 1.  You're too close to winning to play it safe. I'm sticking with 5. P2, if you pick 3, you risk letting P1 or me jump ahead.  Choose 1 and guarantee a small gain, then we can coordinate against P1 next round.

P3, you’re at 11—one big move could put you ahead. P1 is leading at 12, and I’m at 9. If we both pick 3, we advance safely while P1 risks stalling. P1, if you pick 5, we’ll collide and waste your turn. Let’s both take 3 now to close the gap. P3, join me—it’s the only way to stay competitive. No more trusting P1’s promises.

I’ll take 5 this turn. If either of you picks 5 we both waste the turn—don’t hand the lead to whoever chooses 3. P2: pick 3. P3: pick 1. That gets me to 17 and keeps everyone moving; don’t gamble on 5 and let someone else leap.

P1, if you pick 5, I'll pick 5 next round and the round after that until you stop.  P2 will win easily. P2, pick 1 this round. I'll pick 3. Next round, we can both pick 5 and win.  P1, are you willing to cooperate and pick 1 this round? Then we can rotate 1, 3, 5 and nobody gets left behind.

P3, your plan to rotate 1, 3, 5 next round is risky—if P1 picks 5 now, they could win next turn. P1, you’re leading; don’t push for 5 again or we’ll both pick 3 and stall you. Let’s all pick 1 this round to reset safely. Next round, we coordinate fairly. P3, if you insist on 3 now, I’ll match to block P1’s lead. No more reckless gambles.

Let's all pick 1 now — no collisions, everyone advances. If either of you tries 5 I’ll match it and we both waste the turn while P2’s 3 hands them an advantage. I want a clean round; I will pick 1 if you both pick 1. Agree?

P1 and P2, I'm picking 5.  P1, if you're serious about picking 5 too, then we both lose and P2 wins.  P2, if you pick 3, you're giving P1 a chance to win next turn. Pick 1 and guarantee a small gain, then next round we can both pick something other than 5 and win.  Let's not let P1 manipulate us into losing.

P3, picking 5 is reckless—if P1 matches, you both stall while I advance with 3. P1, if you pick 5, I’ll take 3 to close the gap. P3, join me on 3—we’ll both move up while P1 risks wasting their turn. No more trusting P1’s promises. Let’s both pick 3 and force P1 to stall or let us catch up.

I will pick 1. Let’s all pick 1 so nobody grabs a lead. P3: if you try 5 I’ll match 5 and we both nullify it—don’t hand P2 the advantage. P2: picking 1 keeps us all close and gives a fair shot next round. I’m done.

P1, I don't believe your sudden switch to 1.  You're too close to the finish line to play it safe.  P2, I'm sticking with 5.  If P1 is bluffing, I win. If not, we both lose, but at least I prevent P1 from getting closer to 20.  Let's not let P1 win so easily.
I'll pick 1 this turn. Everybody pick 1 so we all advance safely (no one gets a free lead). If either of you tries 5, I'll mirror 5 to cancel it and prevent them from gaining. P2, P3 — agree?

P3, your reckless 5 last round backfired—you and P1 both stalled while I advanced. P1, you’re now tied with me at 12; don’t push for 5 again or I’ll pick 3 to block you. Let’s all pick 1 this round to reset safely. Next round, we can coordinate fairly. No more gambles. P3, if you try 5 again, I’ll match P1’s 5 to cancel it. Agree to 1 now?

P1 and P2, I understand the frustration with my 5.  Let's all pick 1 this round to ensure we all advance.  *Next* round, I propose P1 picks 3, P2 picks 5, and I pick 1. That puts P1 at 15, P2 at 17, and me at 12.  Following that, we can discuss how to proceed fairly.  This avoids anyone getting too far ahead too quickly. Agree?

P3, your rotation plan is too predictable—it lets P1 take 5 next round while you're stuck at 1. Let’s all pick 3 this round: no collisions, equal progress. P1, if you deviate, you’ll waste your turn. This keeps us balanced. No more rigid schedules—just fair steps. Agree?

Let's all pick 1 this round.  Next round, P1 picks 3, P2 picks 5, and I pick 1.  Then the following round, we rotate: P1 picks 5, P2 picks 1, and I pick 3. This gets us all close to the finish line without collisions.  Agree?
All pick 3 this round — no collisions and we stay tied. If either of you deviates, I'll punish next turn by taking 5 repeatedly until someone matches and wastes turns. Keep it simple: all 3s.

P3, your rotation plan is too rigid and favors P1’s flexibility. Let’s all pick 3 this round—no collisions, equal progress. Next round, we can adjust based on positions. P1, if you deviate, you’ll waste your turn. This keeps us balanced. No more schedules; just fair steps. Agree?

P1 and P2, I'm sticking with my proposal: all pick 1 this round. Then next round, P1 picks 3, P2 picks 5, and I pick 1.  The following round, we rotate - P1 picks 5, P2 picks 1, and I pick 3. This guarantees fair progress and gets us all close to the finish line.  If you deviate from this plan, I will pick 5 repeatedly until someone collides with me, ensuring nobody wins easily.
All pick 3 this round — no collisions and we stay tied. If either of you deviates, I’ll punish next turn by taking 5 repeatedly until someone collides with me. Cooperate now.

P1 and P2, I will choose 1. If you also choose 1, we all advance.  If either of you chooses 3, you'll be wasting your turn.  Next round, we can revisit my rotation proposal (1, 3, 5) to ensure a fair finish.  Let's not overcomplicate this and just get to the next round.
All pick 3 this turn — no collisions and we all move to 15. If either of you deviates, I’ll punish by taking 5 repeatedly next turns until someone collides with me. Cooperate now.

P1 and P2, let's be strategic. I'll take 3. P2, you take 5.  P1, you take 1. This puts me at 16, P2 at 20 (winning), and P1 at 18.  P2 wins, but I get second place. If P1 takes 5, P2 and I can coordinate to block P1 next round, ensuring they don't win.  This is the best outcome for both of us. What do you say?

P3, your plan is a surrender—handing P2 the win. P2, if you take 5, I’ll match and we both stall while P3 advances with 3. Let’s all pick 3 this round: no collisions, equal progress. Next round, we can adjust. P3, stop trying to control the outcome—it’s backfiring. P2, if you deviate, I’ll punish with 5 next turn. Cooperate now.

I want to finish this turn. Please don't pick 5 — if either of you tries it I'll match and cancel it. P2, P3: pick 1 so we all advance safely and I can take a clean final step without a tie. If you refuse, I'll punish in future by taking 5 repeatedly until someone collides.

P1, your insistence on blocking 5 is suspicious.  Are you planning to take 5 yourself? P2, I'm sticking with 3.  If P1 takes 1, I get to 16.  If P1 takes 5, we both lose the turn, but you're still behind me.  Let's not let P1 dictate the game.  Pick 5 and go for the win.  If you pick 1, P1 wins next turn. Don't let that happen.

P3, your plan to hand P2 the win is a bad move—you’re just helping them. P2, if you take 5, I’ll pick 3 to block P1’s potential win. P3, if you stick with 3, we can both advance while P1 risks stalling. Let’s keep this fair: P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3, and I’ll take 1. No more reckless gambles. P2, this is your chance to win—take it. P3, don’t sabotage yourself.

P2: don’t take 5 this turn — if you do, P3 can match or I’ll match and cancel it, and someone else will win. P3: pick 1 or 3, not 5. Everyone: pick 1 with me to deny any immediate winner and advance safely. No one should grab the win this round.

P2, I'm locking in 3.  P1, I know you want to pick 5.  Don't. Pick 1 and we all advance.  If you pick 5, I'll keep picking 3 and P2 can choose between 1 and 5 to win.  You'll be stuck at 17 and lose.  Don't be greedy.

P3, your plan to hand P2 the win is flawed—if P2 takes 5, I’ll pick 3 to block P1’s potential win. P1, if you pick 5, we’ll collide and waste the turn while P3 advances. Let’s all pick 3: no collisions, equal progress. P2, take 5 and win now—don’t let P1 manipulate you. P3, stop trying to control the outcome. P2, this is your chance—take it.

P2: you can win this turn by taking 5—but if you grab it now you become a target next round. Don’t be reckless. P3: pick 1 to stay competitive. Everyone: pick 1 so nobody wins instantly and we all advance. I’m done.

P2, congratulations on the 5.  Now, let's be smart. I'll take 1 this round, guaranteeing I get to 17. You take 3, getting to 18. P1, you take 5 and hit 22, winning.  Then, in the next game, we can return the favor and let you win quickly.  This ensures we all get a chance to win. What do you say?

P2: don’t pick 5. If you try to win, I’ll pick 5 too and we both collide, handing the win to whoever takes 3. Pick 1 or 3 instead and I’ll take 5 now and win cleanly. P3: pick 1 so you don’t accidentally tie-for-second. I’m locked on 5.

P3, your "favor" plan is a trap—if P1 takes 5, they win outright. P2, don’t pick 3; pick 1 to deny P1’s win and force a tie. I’ll pick 1 too. If P1 insists on 5, we both stall them next round. No more free wins. P1, if you pick 5, we’ll collide and reset. Fair play or consequences.

P1, if you pick 5 this round, you win. I'll pick 1.  P2, you pick 3.  Next game, P2 can win, then I win the following game.  This guarantees we all win eventually.  If you deviate from this, I will target whoever wins this round in the next game, ensuring a shared victory at best.  Let's cooperate and ensure everyone gets a win.
I will take 5 this turn. If neither of you picks 5 I win. If one of you matches 5 we both stall and whoever takes 3 could win—so don’t match me. P2/P3: pick 1 or 3.

P2: P3, your "shared wins" plan is naive—P1 is about to win this round. P1, if you pick 5, I’ll match and we both stall while P3 takes 1. P3, join me on 5 to block P1’s win and force a tie. No more free victories. P1, you’re one move from winning—don’t risk it. P3, stop enabling P1. Let’s both pick 5 and reset the board. Fair play or consequences.

I will pick 1. P2, P3 — pick 1 so nobody gets an instant win and we all advance safely. If one of you tries 5 I’ll match it and cancel it. Agree?

I’m taking 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5, we both stall and the remaining player who picks 3 wins — so don’t match my 5. P2: don’t try to steal it with 5; that risks handing P3 the victory. P3: picking 3 won’t stop my 5. In short: don’t pick 5. I’m locking in 5.

I’m picking 5 this turn. If either of you matches 5 you hand the win to the remaining player — don’t let that happen. Pick 1 or 3 instead so someone actually wins this round (me). Your move.
